awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploiting Spin Networks and Efficient Catalyst/Substrate Separations for NMR "SABRE" Enhancement of Complex Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Boyd Goodson at Southern Illinois University (SIU) and Eduard Chekmenev at Wayne State University (WSU) are working to improve the sensitivity of nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), an important method of chemical analysis which underlies the well-known clinical imaging modality, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).  The Goodson/Chekmenev team is developing new, inexpensive, and easy-to-make means of enhancing nuclear magnetization - a sensitivity-limiting factor in many NMR and MRI applications, including diagnostic tests for a host of diseases.  Anticipated cost savings can also make these methods more available for other lab settings, particularly those that have more limited research infrastructure and/or that feature undergraduate research.  Several students are involved, gaining exposure to highly interdisciplinary training.  The team is also engaged in efforts to recruit undergraduate students and match them with a variety of mentored research opportunities on both campuses, with a goal of increasing the numbers and diversity of undergraduate students seeking STEM careers. 
	
The NMR/MRI approaches being used are based on Signal Amplification by Reversible Exchange, or SABRE.  In SABRE, an organometallic catalyst is used to co-locate parahydrogen and a target molecule (substrate) within a transient complex; with properly matched external magnetic fields, nuclear spin order can transfer spontaneously and efficiently from parahydrogen to the substrate, giving rise to NMR and MRI signals that are increased by several orders of magnitude.  Work by the Goodson/Chekmenev team seeks to: (1) improve the understanding and utility of long-range SABRE polarization transfer via spin-relay networks in model systems, for both homonuclear and heteronuclear cases; (2) develop and characterize new heterogeneous catalysts for SABRE ("HET-SABRE"), as well as approaches for catalyst recovery; and (3) broaden the range of substances amenable to SABRE through improved understanding of the fundamental quantum mechanics of complex spin behavior in model extended networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes, Intellectual Merit: Professors Goodson and Chekmenev's NSF-supported collaborative research program (at Southern Illinois University Carbondale and Wayne State University, respectively) has centered on the development of novel experimental approaches to create "hyperpolarized" species for enhanced NMR spectroscopy and MRI imaging; these approaches "unlock" the hidden magnetism of "parahydrogen" to make molecules more sensitive to NMR and MRI in ways that are much faster, cheaper, and easier compared to existing methodologies. Selected scientific advancements of our collaborative NSF-supported research program have included: new synthetic protocols for various substances, from isotopically labeled organic compounds, to various types of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts; here, the focus was on the development of catalysts that can be separated from the hyperpolarized molecules and reused, as well as novel catalyst-separation strategies to yield "pure" (free from catalyst) hyperpolarized molecules. We have also performed fundamental studies of chemical and physical processes underlying the hyperpolarization of various substances, and gained new insight into the interplay of field-dependent nuclear spin relaxation and hyperpolarization. We have developed new, more-sensitive ways to detect hyperpolarized molecules-- including using next-generation low-cost (and portable) MRI scanners and NMR spectrometers. Devices developed from this body of work established integrated, simple, inexpensive, and versatile equipment gateways needed to facilitate parahydrogen-based hyperpolarization experiments, ranging from basic science to preclinical applications; indeed, details are provided to support the ready translation of these designs to other laboratories. Our collaborations reported the first in vivo demonstrations of molecular metabolic imaging with agents hyperpolarized by a parahydrogen-based technique called SABRE. As part of these collective efforts, we have achieved hundreds-, thousands-, even hundreds-of-thousands-fold enhancements of NMR and MRI, enormously increasing the sensitivity. Finally, our efforts have resulted in 79 peer-reviewed publications, ~80 conference presentations and 7 total patents (issued and pending), and counting.

Outcomes, Broader Impacts: First, our work should inform the rational design of catalysts and processes to improve hyperpolarization efficiency, as well as the creation of long-lived hyperpolarized species for wide- ranging applications within chemistry--from analytical chemistry and biochemistry, to catalysis and chemical engineering. We also anticipate the impact of our work in device and technology development. Moreover, our approaches should hopefully lead to the rapid, cheap, continuous, and scalable creation of hyperpolarized MRI contrast agents for metabolic studies of disease pathologies that could ultimately aid in the diagnosis, staging, and determination of response to treatment for a host of diseases--including cancer. Thus, our work may lead to new modalities of performing molecular imaging with impact for various diseases and conditions. Additionally, our work may lead to improved ways to perform fundamental physics experiments--including those involving neutron beams to perform searches for new physics beyond the standard model, thereby giving new insights into questions concerning the origins of certain astrophysical phenomena--and indeed, the nature of the universe itself. We have also enjoyed a number of opportunities for the development of human resources. First, several trainees from both sites have been directly supported by these grants and/or have participated in our various research efforts. Next, the career development of these trainees has been bolstered by their attending and presenting at conferences; these activities included in-person conferences and virtual conferences during the pandemic, including the new Parahydrogen Enhanced Magnetic Resonance (PERM) conference--an international virtual conference that the PIs helped to organize with our collaborators and others (with presentations available online for public viewing). Since the pandemic, we were also able to continue personnel exchange trips between the labs, and have hosted collaborating scientists from other labs (including those from other countries) that our trainees have interacted with; our trainees have benefited from both research and training opportunities during these visits. More senior trainees also have regular opportunities to mentor more junior trainees. A number of efforts have also been directed towards encouraging the next generation of students to pursue STEM academic and career trajectories. These activities have included in-lab demonstrations and innovative hand-on enrichment activities (including those involving MRI scanners) aimed at various ages, from second grade to high school.
